review.title: Informal Physical Reasoning Processes
review.abstract: A fundamental question is whether Turing machines can model all reasoning processes. We introduce an existence principle stating that the perception of the physical existence of any Turing program can serve as a physical causation for the application of any Turing-computable function to this Turing program. The existence principle overcomes the limitation of the outputs of Turing machines to lists, that is, recursively enumerable sets. The principle is illustrated by productive partial functions for productive sets such as the set of the Goedel numbers of the Turing-computable total functions. The existence principle and productive functions imply the existence of physical systems whose reasoning processes cannot be modeled by Turing machines. These systems are called creative. Creative systems can prove the undecidable formula in Goedel's theorem in another formal system which is constructed at a later point in time. A hypothesis about creative systems, which is based on computer experiments, is introduced.

metadata.title: Informal Physical Reasoning Processes

sections.text: ar Xiv: 160 8.04 672v 1 [cs.A I] 1 5A ugA fundamental question is whether Turing machines can model all thought processes. We introduce a principle of existence that states that the perception of the physical existence of a Turing program can serve as the physical cause for the application of any Turing calculable function to this Turing program. The principle of existence overcomes the limitation of the outputs of Turing machines to lists, i.e. recursively enumerable sets. The principle is illustrated by productive partial functions for productive sets, such as the set of Go-del numbers of the Turing calculable total functions. Existence principle and productive functions imply the existence of physical systems whose thought processes cannot be modeled by Turing machines. These systems are creatively called. Creative systems can prove the indecipherable formula in Godel's theorem in another formal system that is experimented at a later date based on a computer hypothesis.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Turing [1969, p. 21, and 1948, p. 17, in the original typewriter is fixed any program that requires a certain intelligence.] discusses the evolution of intelligence in man and in machines: If the untrained child mind is an intelligent one, it must acquire both discipline and initiative.... Our task is to discover the nature of this resistance as it occurs in man, and to try to copy it into a universal machine. [Turing] Discipline is thus the execution of a universal [Turing] discipline, that is, the execution of an ordinary computer program. "What is additionally required to produce intelligence, we call initiative." This means that Turing assumes that intelligence cannot be fully represented by any other correspondence kurtammon.

sections.heading: 3 Reasoning
sections.text: The Turing program Pi in the input of the physical rule (3) in section 2 can therefore be interpreted as a proposed description of the sequence (4) in section 2 produced by the creative system C in Theorem 1. C applies the productive function of Pi in (3) to the aspect i of Pi, that is, to the proposed description of the sequence (4). sections.heading: 4 Discussion
sections.text: In this sense, it is not surprising that, in recent years, there have been repeated arguments about the question of whether the question of why is a purely formal question, whether the question of why is a purely formal question, whether the question of why is a purely formal question, whether the question of why is a formal question, whether it is a formal question, whether it is a formal question, whether it is a question, whether it is not a formal question, whether it is a question, whether it is a question, whether it is a question, whether it is a question, whether it is a question, whether it is a question, whether it is a question, whether it is a question, whether it is not a question, whether it is a question, whether it is not a question.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion
sections.text: The principle of physical existence states that the perception of the physical existence of a Turing program can serve as physical causality for the application of Turing computable functions to this Turing program. The principle of logical existence abstracts the logical aspects from the principle of physical existence. It is used to prove a theorem that states that a physical rule, which represents the implementation of the principle of existence, produces a sequence that cannot be calculated by any Turing program. The principle of logical existence can be considered a new principle of logic that has never been used before in a mathematical proof. The principle of existence overcomes the incompleteness of formal systems and the limitations of the Turing machines because it describes the perception of the physical existence of Turing programs as a whole. This allows a general reference and application of formal systems to themselves as a whole that cannot be achieved within formal systems themselves.
